usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.1 (0) - Create
usecase.description:
In this use-case the client issues a Create request,
whereby the server creates a new symmetric key and
returns the Unique Identifier.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
objectType = 00000002 (Symmetric Key),
attributes = {
CryptographicAlgorithm = 00000003 (AES),
CryptographicLength = 128,
CryptographicUsageMask = 0000000C
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.1 (1) - Destroy
usecase.description:
To clean up after "UC 3.1.1 - Create", the client
then performs a Destroy operation to destroy the key.
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.2 (0) - Register Template
usecase.description: The client registers a template object.
usecase.details:
Register (template)
objectType = 00000007 (Template),
TemplateAttribute = empty,
Template = {
ObjectGroup = 'Group1',
ApplicationSpecificInformation = 'ssl, www.example.com',
ContactInformation=’Joe’,
x-Purpose=’demonstration’,
Name={
NameValue=’Template1’,
NameType=’00000001’
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.2 (1) - Create Symmetric Key using Template
usecase.description:
The Client creates a Symmetric Key
using the registered Template
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key using template)
ObjectType = 00000002 (Symmetric Key),
Template = {
NameValue = 'Template1'
NameType = '00000001'
}
Attributes = {
CryptographicAlgorithm = 00000003 (AES),
CryptographicLength = 128,
CryptographicUsageMask = 0000000C
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.2 (2) - Get Attributes
usecase.description:
To verify that the attributes of the key
were set correctly from the template,
the client then issues a Get Attributes
command.
usecase.details:
Get attributes
In: uuidKey,
attributeNames = {
'Object Group',
'ApplicationSpecificInformation',
'ContactInformation',
'x-Purpose'
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.2 (3) - Destroy Key
usecase.description: The Client destroys the key.
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.2 (4) - Destroy Template
usecase.description: The Client destroys the template.
usecase.details:
Destroy (template)
In: uuidTemplate

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.3 (0) - Create
usecase.description:
This use-case tests the Locate and Get
operations, in addition to the previously
used operations Create and Destroy.
First, a symmetric key is created.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
ObjectType = 00000002 (Symmetric Key),
Attributes = {
Name = {
NameValue = 'Key1',
NameType = '00000001'
}
CryptographicAlgorithm = 00000002 (3DES),
CryptographicLength = 56,
CryptographicUsageMask = 0000000C,
ContactInformation = 'Joe'
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.3 (1) - Locate
usecase.description: Locate the key
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key)
In:
Attributes = {
ObjectType = 00000002,
Name = {
Name = Key1,
NameType = 00000001
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.3 (2) - Get
usecase.description:
A Get request is issued to retrieve the
located key
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.3 (3) - Destroy
usecase.description: Destroy the key.
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.3 (4) - Locate
usecase.description:
After the key on the server is destroyed,
a Locate request is issued.
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (0) - Client A: Register Template
usecase.description:
This use-case has two clients (A,B) performing
operations on the same key. The first client
initially registers a template.
This use-case demonstrates the fact that it is
possible for two clients to cooperate and use
the same managed object while only having
knowledge of a single pre-agreed Name
attribute value and without having to share
any other information.
usecase.details:
Register (template)
In:
objectType=’00000007’,
TemplateAttribute=empty,
Template=
{
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
Name={ NameValue=’Template1’, NameType=’00000001’ },
} Locate (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (1) - Client A: Create Symmetric Key using Template
usecase.description: The first client creates a key using the template.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key using template)
ObjectType = 00000002 (Symmetric Key),
Template = { NameValue= ‘Template1’, NameType=’00000001’ },
Attributes =
{
Name={ Name=‘Key1’, NameType=’00000001’ },
CryptographicUsageMask=‘00000004’,
ContactInformation=‘Foo’
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (2) - Client B: Locate and Get Symmetric-Key by Name
usecase.description:
The second client then does a batched Locate and Get using
the ID Placeholder to retrieve the key.
usecase.details:
Locate and Get (symmetric key by name)
In (header): batchOrderOption=’TRUE’
In: attributes =
{
objectType = ‘00000002’,
Name={ Name=‘Key1’, NameType=’00000001’}
}
In: empty Get payload

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (3) - Client B: Get Attribute List
usecase.description:
The second client thereafter performs a number of
operations on the key (Get Attribute List,
Get Attribute, Add Attribute, Modify Attribute
and Delete Attribute).
usecase.details:
Get Attribute List
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (4) - Client B: Get Attributes
usecase.description:
The second client thereafter performs a number of
operations on the key (Get Attribute List,
Get Attribute, Add Attribute, Modify Attribute
and Delete Attribute).
usecase.details:
Get Attributes
In: uuidKey
attributeNames={‘Name’, ‘ContactInformation’}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (5) - Client B: Add Attribute
usecase.description:
The second client thereafter performs a number of
operations on the key (Get Attribute List,
Get Attribute, Add Attribute, Modify Attribute
and Delete Attribute).
usecase.details:
Add attribute [batch]
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute1=‘Value1’}
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute2=‘Value2’ }

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (6) - Client B: Modify Attribute
usecase.description:
The second client thereafter performs a number of
operations on the key (Get Attribute List,
Get Attribute, Add Attribute, Modify Attribute
and Delete Attribute).
usecase.details:
Modify attribute [batch]
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute1=‘ModifiedValue1’ }
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute2=‘ModifiedValue2’ }

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (7) - Client B: Delete Attribute
usecase.description:
The second client thereafter performs a number of
operations on the key (Get Attribute List,
Get Attribute, Add Attribute, Modify Attribute
and Delete Attribute).
usecase.details:
Delete attribute [batch]
In: uuidKey, attributeNames={‘x-attribute1’}
In: uuidKey, attributeNames={‘x-attribute2’}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (8) - Client A: Destroy Symmetric-Key
usecase.description: The first client destroys the key.
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (9) - Client A: Get Symmetric-Key
usecase.description:
The first client tries to Get the key
after it has been destroyed, but
the Get operation fails.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (10) - Client A: Destroy Template
usecase.description: The first client destroys the template.
usecase.details:
Destroy (template)
In: uuidTemplate

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.4 (11) - Client A: Get Template
usecase.description:
The first client tries to Get the template
after it has been destroyed, but
the Get operation fails.
usecase.details:
Get (template)
In: uuidTemplate

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.5 (0) - Register (secret data)
usecase.description:
The client issues a Register request containing
a Secret Data object, whereby the server registers
the object and returns the Unique Identifier.
usecase.details:
Register (secret data)
In: objectType = '00000007' (Secret Data)
attributes = {
CryptographicUsageMask = '00000002' (Verify)}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.1.5 (1) - Destroy (secret data)
usecase.description:
To clean up, the client performs a Destroy operation
to destroy the object
usecase.details:
Destroy (secret data)
In: uuidObject

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (0) - Client A: Create Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
This use-case tests the asynchronous capabilities
of KMIP using the Locate operation. A key is created
and then a Locate request is sent containing the Name of
the created key and with the message header
Asynchronous Indicator-field set to True. If the server
returns an asynchronous response to the Locate, the
client then polls the server until the operation is
ready. If the server responded asynchronously,
a subsequent Locate operation that is also handled
asynchronously is then Cancelled, before the key is
finally destroyed.
This use-case shows the use of two clients with
the same assumptions as in the use-case described
in Section 3.1.4 Since the client is unable to
force the server to respond asynchronously, it is
possible for a server to respond synchronously to
the requests issued at times 1 and 4, in which case
the expected response are the ones shown at times 2
and 5, respectively. In the case of the server not
responding asynchronously to the Locate requests,
the client is permitted to skip the requests
illustrated at time 7 and 8.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
Name={ NameValue=‘Key1’, NameType=’00000001’ },
CryptographicUsageMask=‘00000004’
ObjectGroup =‘Group1’
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (1) - Client B: Locate Symmetric Key by Name
usecase.description:
A Locate request is sent containing the Name of
the created key and with the message header
Asynchronous Indicator-field set to True.
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key by name)
In: asynchronousIndicator = 'TRUE',
attributes={
objectType = ‘00000002’
Name={ NameValue=‘Key1’, NameType=’00000001’ },
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (2) - Client B: Poll*
usecase.description:
If the server returns an asynchronous response
to the Locate, the client then polls the server
until the operation is ready.
usecase.details:
Poll*
In: asyncCorrValue1

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (3) - Client B: Get Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
If the server returns an asynchronous response
to the Locate, the client then polls the server
until the operation is ready.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey1

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (4) - Client B: Locate Symmetric Key by Group
usecase.description:
A Locate request is sent containing the Group of
the created key and with the message header
Asynchronous Indicator-field set to True.
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key by group)
In: asynchronousIndicator = 'TRUE',
attributes={
objectType = ‘00000002’
objectGroup= 'Group1',
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (5) - Client B: Poll*
usecase.description:
If the server returns an asynchronous response
to the Locate, the client then polls the server
until the operation is ready.
usecase.details:
Poll*
In: asyncCorrValue2

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (6) - Client B: Get Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
If the server responded asynchronously,
a subsequent Locate operation that is also handled
asynchronously is then Cancelled, before the key is
finally destroyed.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey2

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (7) - Client B: Locate Symmetric Key by Name
usecase.description:
If the server responded asynchronously,
a subsequent Locate operation that is also handled
asynchronously is then Cancelled, before the key is
finally destroyed.
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key by name)
In: asynchronousIndicator = 'TRUE',
attributes={
objectType = ‘00000002’
Name= {Name = 'Key1', NameType = '00000001'},
}

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (8) - Client B: Cancel
usecase.description:
If the server responded asynchronously,
a subsequent Locate operation that is also handled
asynchronously is then Cancelled, before the key is
finally destroyed.
usecase.details:
Cancel
In: asyncCorrValue5

usecase.name: Use Case 3.2 (9) - Client B: Destroy Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
If the server responded asynchronously,
a subsequent Locate operation that is also handled
asynchronously is then Cancelled, before the key is
finally destroyed.
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (0) - Client A: Create Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
This use-case tests the revocation aspect
of the key life cycle support in KMIP.
First, a Symmetric Key is created.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
Name={ NameValue=‘Key1’, NameType=’00000001’ },
CryptographicUsageMask=‘00000004’
}

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (1) - Client A: Get Attributes
usecase.description:
A Get Attribute for the State-attribute
reveals that the key is in Pre-active state.
usecase.details:
Get attribute
In: uuidKey,
attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (2) - Client A: Activate
usecase.description:
The Activation Date is then set,
which changes the state to Active.
usecase.details:
Activate
In: uuidKey,

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (3) - Client A: Get Attributes
usecase.description:
A Get Attribute for the State-attribute
reveals that the key has changed to the Active state.
usecase.details:
Get attribute
In: uuidKey,
attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (4) - Client B: Locate
usecase.description:
Client B locates the Key using the Object Type
and Name.
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key by name)
In: objectType = '00000002',
attributes = {
Name = { Name = 'Key1', NameType = '00000001'}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (5) - Client B: Get
usecase.description:
Client B performes a Get Operation on
the located key.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (6) - Client B: Revoke
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to add, modify and delete attributes
or even get the key (since we assume here that the
out-of-band registration has been used to make
the server aware of the fact that the client is
capable of interpreting the attributes of the key
and determining what it is allowed to do with the key).
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as compromised)
In: uuidKey,
RevocationReason = '00000002',
CompromiseOccurrenceDate = '6' (Thu Jan 01 01:00:06 CET 1970)

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (7) - Client B: Get Attribute
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to add, modify and delete attributes.
usecase.details:
Get attribute
In: uuidKey,
attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (8) - Client A: Get Attribute List
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to add, modify and delete attributes.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute List
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (9) - Client A: Get Attributes
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to add, modify and delete attributes.
usecase.details:
Get attributes
In: uuidKey,
attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (10) - Client A: Add Attribute
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to add, modify and delete attributes.
usecase.details:
Add attribute [batch]
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute1=‘Value1’}
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute2=‘Value2’ }

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (11) - Client A: Modify Attribute
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to add, modify and delete attributes.
usecase.details:
Modify attribute [batch]
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute1=‘ModifiedValue1’ }
In: uuidKey, attribute={ x-attribute2=‘ModifiedValue2’ }

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (12) - Client A: Delete Attribute
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to add, modify and delete attributes.
usecase.details:
Delete attribute [batch]
In: uuidKey, attributeNames={‘x-attribute1’}
In: uuidKey, attributeNames={‘x-attribute2’}

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (13) - Client A: Get Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to get the key (since we assume here
that the out-of-band registration has been used to
make the server aware of the fact that the client is
capable of interpreting the attributes of the key
and determining what it is allowed to do with the key).
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 4.1 (14) - Client A: Destroy Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
The key is then revoked with a revocation reason
of Compromised and the state subsequently changed
to Compromised, but this does not stop a client
from being able to get the key (since we assume here
that the out-of-band registration has been used to
make the server aware of the fact that the client is
capable of interpreting the attributes of the key
and determining what it is allowed to do with the key).
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (0) - Client A: Create Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
This use-case tests the usage management functionality
of KMIP. A key is created and the Activation Date and
Protect Stop Date attributes are set in such a way as
to allow the Get Usage Allocation operation to be
performed. The value of the Usage Limits attribute is
set to 1000 bytes, and two subsequent requests for 500
bytes succeed (one of them also verifying the amount
that can be received using the Check operation), while
a third fails since the usage allocation has been used
up. The key is finally revoked and destroyed. This
use-case shows the use of multiple clients with the
assumptions regarding the clients being the same as in
the use-case described in Section 3.1.4
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
Name={ NameValue=‘Key1’, NameType=’00000001’ },
CryptographicUsageMask=‘00000004’
}

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (1) - Client A: Add Attributes
usecase.description:
A key is created and the Activation Date and
Protect Stop Date attributes are set in such a way as
to allow the Get Usage Allocation operation to be
performed.
usecase.details:
Add attribute [batch]
In: uuidKey, attribute={ ActivationDate=‘2’ }
In: uuidKey, attribute={ ProtectStopDate=’’ }

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (2) - Client A: Add Attribute
usecase.description:
The value of the Usage Limits attribute is
set to 1000 bytes.

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (3) - Client B: Locate Symmetric Key by Name
usecase.description: Locate the key, which was created by Client A.
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key by name)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’,
attributes={ Name={ Name=‘Key1’, NameType= ‘00000001’} }

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (4) - Client B: Get Symmetric Key
usecase.description: Get the located symmetric key
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (5) - Client B: Check & Get Usage Allocation
usecase.description:
two subsequent requests for 500
bytes succeed (one of them also verifying the amount
that can be received using the Check operation), while
a third fails since the usage allocation has been used
up.
usecase.details:
Check
Get usage allocation
In (header): BatchOrderOption=’true’
In: uuidKey, UsageLimitsCount=’500’
In: uuidKey, UsageLimitsCount=’500’

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (6) - Client A: Get Usage Allocation
usecase.description:
(one of them also verifying the amount
that can be received using the Check operation)
usecase.details:
Get usage allocation
In: uuidKey, UsageLimitsCount=’500’

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (7) - Client C: Locate Symmetric Key by Name
usecase.description: Locate the key, which was created by Client A.
usecase.details:
Locate (symmetric key by name)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’,
attributes={ Name={ Name=‘Key1’, NameType= ‘00000001’} }

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (8) - Client C: Get Symmetric Key
usecase.description: Get the located symmetric key
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (9) - Client C: Get Usage Allocation
usecase.description:
a third fails since the usage allocation has been used
up.
usecase.details:
Get usage allocation
In: uuidKey, UsageLimitsCount=’500’

usecase.name: Use Case 5.1 (10) - Client A: Revoke and Destroy
usecase.description:
The key is finally revoked and destroyed. This
use-case shows the use of multiple clients with the
assumptions regarding the clients being the same as in
the use-case described in Section 3.1.4
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as cessation of operation) and Destroy (symmetric key)
In (header): batchOrderOption=’TRUE’
In: uuidKey, revocationReasonCode=’6’
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 6.1 (0) - Register Symmetric Key
usecase.description:
This use-case tests the import of a foreign key using
the Register operation. To validate that the registered
key is treated the same as a locally created key, an attribute
is added to the key and then modified. Finally, the key
is destroyed.
usecase.details:
Register (symmetric key)
In: objectType = '00000002',
attributes = {
CryptographicUsageMask = '00000004' (Encrypt)
}
foreignSymmetricKey

usecase.name: Use Case 6.1 (1) - Add attribute
usecase.description: An attribute is added to the key and then modified.
usecase.details:
Add attribute
In: uuidKey,
attribute = {
x-provider = 'unknown'
}

usecase.name: Use Case 6.1 (2) - Modify Attribute
usecase.description: An attribute is added to the key and then modified.
usecase.details:
Modify attribute
In: uuidKey,
attribute = {
x-provider = 'third party'
}

usecase.name: Use Case 6.1 (3) - Destroy
usecase.description: Finally, the key is destroyed.
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 7.1 (0) - Create
usecase.description:
A create request is issued and the request contains
a Message Extension with the Criticality Indicator
set to false. The server does not understand the
extension, but since it is non-critical, the create
request is processed normally. Subsequently, the
created key is deleted.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = '00000002',
attributes = {
CryptographicAlgorithm = 'AES',
CryptographicLength = '128',
CryptographicUsageMask = '0000000C'
}
Message Extension = {
VendorIdentification = 'Acme',
CriticalityIndicator = 'false',
VendorExtension = {
tag = '0x540001',
type = 'text string',
value = 'na'
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 7.1 (1) - Destroy
usecase.description: Subsequently, the created key is deleted.
usecase.details:
Destroy (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 7.2 (0) - Create
usecase.description:
A create request is issued and the request contains
a Message Extension with the Criticality Indicator
set to true. The server does not understand the
extension, and since it is critical, the create
request fails and an error is returned.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = '00000002',
attributes = {
CryptographicAlgorithm = 'AES',
CryptographicLength = '128',
CryptographicUsageMask = '0000000C'
}
Message Extension = {
VendorIdentification = 'Acme',
CriticalityIndicator = 'true',
VendorExtension = {
tag = '0x540001',
type = 'text string',
value = 'na'
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 8.1 (0) - Create Key Pair
usecase.description:
Create a new private/public key pair.
Make sure they are linked correctly by issuing
Locate commands with the assigned Unique Identifiers
Finally delete both key halves.
usecase.details:
Create Key Pair
In: commonAttributes = {
CryptographicAlgorithm = 'RSA',
CryptographicLength = '1024'
}
privateKeyAttributes = {
Name = {
NameValue = 'PrivateKey1,
NameType = '00000001'
}
CryptographicUsageMask = '00000001',
}
publicKeyAttributes = {
Name = {
NameValue = 'PublicKey1,
NameType = '00000001'
}
CryptographicUsageMask = '00000002',
}

usecase.name: Use Case 8.1 (1) - Locate (Public Key)
usecase.description:
Make sure the keys are linked correctly by issuing
Locate commands with the assigned Unique Identifiers
usecase.details:
Locate (Public Key)
In: attributes = {
objectType = 'PublicKey',
Link = {
LinkType = 'PrivateKeyLink',
LinkedObjectIdentifier = uuidPrivateKey
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 8.1 (2) - Locate (Private Key)
usecase.description:
Make sure the keys are linked correctly by issuing
Locate commands with the assigned Unique Identifiers
usecase.details:
Locate (Private Key)
In: attributes = {
objectType = 'PrivateKey',
Link = {
LinkType = 'PublicKeyLink',
LinkedObjectIdentifier = uuidPrivateKey
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 8.1 (3) - Destroy (Private Key)
usecase.description: Finally, destroy both key halves.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidPrivateKey

usecase.name: Use Case 8.1 (4) - Destroy (Public Key)
usecase.description: Finally, destroy both key halves.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidPublicKey

usecase.name: Use Case 8.2 (0) - Register (Private Key)
usecase.description:
Register a private key and a public key and set
the Link attribute to point to each other.
Verify the links were set correctly by locating
the keys based on the link attributes, and then
delete both objects.
usecase.details:
Register (Private Key)
In: objectType = '00000004',
attributes = {
CryptographicUsageMask = '00000001'
}
foreignPrivateKey

usecase.name: Use Case 8.2 (1) - Register (Public Key)
usecase.description:
Register a private key and a public key and set
the Link attribute to point to each other.
usecase.details:
Register (Public Key)
In: objectType = '00000004',
attributes = {
CryptographicUsageMask = '00000002',
Link = {
LinkType = 'PrivateKeyLink',
LinkedObjectIdentifier = uuidPrivateKey
}
}
foreignPublicKey

usecase.name: Use Case 8.2 (2) - Add Attribute
usecase.description: Set the link attribute to point to each other.
usecase.details:
Add attribute
In: uuidPrivateKey,
attribute = {
Link = {
LinkType = 'PublicKeyLink',
LinkedObjectIdentifier = uuidPublicKey
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 8.2 (3) - Locate (Public Key)
usecase.description:
Verify the links were set correctly by locating
the keys based on the link attributes.
usecase.details:
Locate (Public Key)
In: attributes = {
objectType = 'PublicKey',
Link = {
LinkType = 'PrivateKeyLink',
LinkedObjectIdentifier = uuidPrivateKey
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 8.2 (4) - Locate (Private Key)
usecase.description:
Verify the links were set correctly by locating
the keys based on the link attributes.
usecase.details:
Locate (Private Key)
In: attributes = {
objectType = 'PrivateKey',
Link = {
LinkType = 'PublicKeyLink',
LinkedObjectIdentifier = uuidPublicKey
}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 8.2 (5) - Destroy (Private Key)
usecase.description: Delete both Objects.
usecase.details:
Destroy (Private Key)
In: uuidPrivateKey

usecase.name: Use Case 8.2 (6) - Destroy (Public Key)
usecase.description: Delete both Objects.
usecase.details:
Destroy (Public Key)
In: uuidPublicKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (0) - Create (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Create a symmetric key with a specific name, and then
use Locate to find the key. After using Re-key to create
a new key, verify that the name was removed from the existing
key and copied to the new key. Also verify that the key material
for the old key is still retrievable. To clean up,
both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
CryptographicUsageMask=‘0000000C’
Name={ NameValue=‘rekeyKey’, NameType=’00000001’ },
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (1) - Locate
usecase.description: Use Locate to find the key.
usecase.details:
Locate
In: attributes{
Name = { NameValue = 'rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (2) - Re Key
usecase.description: Use Re-key to create a new key.
usecase.details:
Rekey
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (3) - Locate
usecase.description:
After using Re-key to create a new key,
verify that the name was removed from the existing
key and copied to the new key.
usecase.details:
Locate
In: attributes{
Name = { NameValue = 'rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (4) - Get Attributes
usecase.description:
After using Re-key to create a new key,
verify that the name was removed from the existing
key and copied to the new key.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidKey,
attributeName = {'Name'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (5) - Get (Symmetric Key)
usecase.description:
Also verify that the key material
for the old key is still retrievable.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (6) - Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.1 (7) - Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidNewKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (0) - Create (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Create a new symmetric key. Then add the Activation
Date and Deactivation Date attributes based on the
timestamp in the response to the Create request.
The Activation Date is set to a time in the past and
the Deactivation Date to a time in the near future.
Repeated Get Attribute calls are performed to verify
that the state is first “Active”, then subsequently
“Deactivated”. Then issue a Re-key request, including
an Activation Date attribute with the value set to the
previously specified Deactivation Date of the existing
key. Verify from the response that the Activation Date
and Deactivation Date attributes were set correctly
(if they are not returned, issue a Get Attribute
request). Do a Get Attribute operation to verify
that the state of the new key is “Active”.
To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
CryptographicUsageMask=‘0000000C’
Name = { NameValue = 'rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (1) - Add Activation Date, Deactivation Date
usecase.description:
Then add the Activation Date and Deactivation Date
attributes based on the timestamp in the response to
the Create request. The Activation Date is set to a time
in the past and the Deactivation Date to a time
in the near future.
usecase.details:
Add Activation Date, Deactivation Date attributes based on
Timestamp in previous response (batch)
In: uuidKey, attribute={ ActivationDate =
''}
In: uuidKey, attribute={ DeactivationDate =
''}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (2) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
Repeated Get Attribute calls are performed to verify
that the state is first “Active”, then subsequently
“Deactivated”.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute * Repeated until state changes to Deactivated
In: uuidKey, attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (3) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
Repeated Get Attribute calls are performed to verify
that the state is first “Active”, then subsequently
“Deactivated”.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidKey, attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (4) - Re Key
usecase.description:
Then issue a Re-key request, including an Activation Date
attribute with the value set to the previously
specified Deactivation Date of the existing
key. Verify from the response that the Activation Date
and Deactivation Date attributes were set correctly
(if they are not returned, issue a Get Attribute
request)
usecase.details:
Rekey
In: uuidKey,
attribute = {offset = 'FE747E00' (300 days backwards)}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (5) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
Verify from the response that the Activation Date
and Deactivation Date attributes were set correctly
(if they are not returned, issue a Get Attribute
request).
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidNewKey,
attributeName = {'ActivationDate', 'DeactivationDate'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (6) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
Do a Get Attribute operation to verify
that the state of the new key is “Active”.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidNewKey,
attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (7) - Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidNewKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.2 (8) - Revoke and Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as cessation of operation) and Destroy
In (header): batchOrderOption = 'TRUE'
In: uuidKey, revocationReasonCode = '6'
In: uuidNewKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (0) - Create (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Create a new symmetric key with the Activation Date
in the past. Do a Get Attribute operation on the State
attribute to verify the key is “Active”. Then revoke
the key as compromised, verify that the state has changed
to “Compromised”. Create a replacement key using Re-key
with the offset set to ‘0’ to indicate that the times are
to be copied from the existing key. Do a Get Attribute
operation to verify that the state of the new key is
“Active”. To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
CryptographicUsageMask=‘0000000C’
Name = { NameValue = 'rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'},
ActivationDate = '' }
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (1) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
Do a Get Attribute operation on the State
attribute to verify the key is “Active”.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidKey, attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (2) - Revoke
usecase.description: Then revoke the key as compromised.
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as compromised)
In: uuidKey, RevocationReason = '00000002',
CompromiseOccurrenceDate = ''

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (3) - Get Attribute
usecase.description: Verify that the state has changed to “Compromised”.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidKey, attributeName = {'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (4) - Re Key
usecase.description:
Create a replacement key using Re-key with the
offset set to ‘0’ to indicate that the times are
to be copied from the existing key.
usecase.details:
Rekey
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (5) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
Do a Get Attribute operation to verify that the
state of the new key is “Active”.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidNewKey, attributeName={'State'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (6) - Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.3 (7) - Revoke and Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as cessation of operation) and Destroy
In (header): batchOrderOption = 'TRUE'
In: uuidNewKey, revocationReasonCode = '6'
In: uuidNewKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (0) - Create (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Create a symmetric key with a specific name,
then use Locate to find the key. After using
Re-key to create a new key, verify that the name
was removed from the existing key and copied to
the new key. To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
CryptographicUsageMask=‘0000000C’
Name = { NameValue = 'rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'},
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (1) - Locate
usecase.description: Use Locate to find the key.
usecase.details:
Locate
In: attributes = {
Name = { NameValue = 'rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'},
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (2) - Re Key
usecase.description:
After using Re-key to create a new key, verify that
the name was removed from the existing key and copied to
the new key.
usecase.details:
Rekey
In: uuidKey,
attributes= {
ActivationDate=’0000000043B7B630’,
ProcessStartDate=’0000000043B7B630’,
ProtectStopDate=’000000005E0C7BB0’,
DeactivationDate=’000000005E0C7BB0’
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (3) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
After using Re-key to create a new key, verify that
the name was removed from the existing key and copied to
the new key.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidKey, attributeName = {'Name'}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (4) - Get Attribute
usecase.description:
After using Re-key to create a new key, verify that
the name was removed from the existing key and copied to
the new key.
usecase.details:
Get Attribute
In: uuidKey, attributeName = {
'ActivationDate', 'ProcessStartDate',
'ProtectStopDate', 'DeactivationDate',
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (5) - Locate
usecase.description:
After using Re-key to create a new key, verify that
the name was removed from the existing key and copied to
the new key.
usecase.details:
Locate
In: attributes = {
Name = { NameValue='rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (6) - Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.4 (7) - Revoke and Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as cessation of operation) and Destroy
In (header): batchOrderOption = 'TRUE'
In: uuidNewKey, revocationReasonCode = '6'
In: uuidNewKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (0) - Client A: Create (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Create a symmetric key with a specific name and
obtain a lease. Revoke the key with state
“Compromised” and re-key the key. Try to obtain a
lease on the old key which fails. Locate the new
key with the original name. Get the new key and
obtain a lease.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
CryptographicUsageMask=‘0000000C’
Name = { NameValue = 'rekeyKey', NameType = '00000001'},
ActivationDate=’’
}

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (1) - Client A: Get (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Create a symmetric key with a specific name and
obtain a lease.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (2) - Client A: Obtain Lease
usecase.description:
Create a symmetric key with a specific name and
obtain a lease.
usecase.details:
Obtain Lease
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (3) - Client B: Revoke
usecase.description: Revoke the key with state “Compromised”
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as compromised)
In: uuidKey, RevocationReason = '00000002',
CompromiseOccurrenceDate = ''

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (4) - Client B: Re Key
usecase.description: Rekey the compromised key
usecase.details:
Rekey
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (5) - Client A: Obtain Lease
usecase.description: Try to obtain a lease on the old key which fails.
usecase.details:
Obtain Lease
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (6) - Client A: Locate (symmetric key)
usecase.description: Locate the new key with the original name.

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (7) - Client A: Get (symmetric key)
usecase.description: Get the new key
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (8) - Client A: Obtain Lease
usecase.description: ... and obtain a lease.
usecase.details:
Obtain Lease
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (9) - Client A: Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 9.5 (10) - Client A: Revoke and Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, both keys are deleted.
usecase.details:
Revoke (symmetric key as cessation of operation) and Destroy
In (header): batchOrderOption = 'TRUE'
In: uuidNewKey, revocationReasonCode = '6'
In: uuidNewKey

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (0) - Create (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Create a symmetric key with a specified name,
then use Locate to find the key and get the key.
Archive the key (asynchronous operation, use Poll
until it completes) and use Get and Locate on it,
but both fail. Add the Storage Status Mask to the
Locate-command, indicating to the server to search
in both online and archived storage. The Locate
finds the key. Recover the key from the archive
(also asynchronous), both Locate and Get succeed.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In: objectType = ‘00000002’
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
CryptographicUsageMask=‘0000000C’
Name = { NameValue = 'archiveKey', NameType = '00000001'},
}

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (1) - Locate
usecase.description: Locate the new key with the original name.

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (2) - Get (symmetric key)
usecase.description: Get the new key
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (3) - Archive
usecase.description: Archive the key (asynchronous operation)
usecase.details:
Archive
In: uuidKey,
asynchronousIndicator=’true’
Out: asynchronousCorrelationValue

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (4) - Poll
usecase.description:
Use Poll until it completes then use Get and Locate,
but both fail.
usecase.details:
Poll*
In: asynchronousCorrelationValue

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (5) - Get (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Use Poll until it completes then use Get and Locate,
but both fail.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (6) - Get Attributes (Archive Date)
usecase.description:
Use Poll until it completes then use Get and Locate,
but both fail.
usecase.details:
Get Attributes (Archive Date)
In: uuidKey,
attributeName=’ArchiveDate’

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (7) - Locate
usecase.description:
Use Poll until it completes then use Get and Locate,
but both fail.
usecase.details:
Locate
In: attributes={
Name={ NameValue=‘archiveKey’, NameType=’00000001’ }
}
Out: ''

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (8) - Locate
usecase.description:
Add the Storage Status Mask to the
Locate-command, indicating to the server to search
in both online and archived storage. The Locate
finds the key.
usecase.details:
Locate
In: storageStatusMask=’00000003’
attributes={
Name={ NameValue=‘archiveKey’, NameType=’00000001’ }
}
Out: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (9) - Recover
usecase.description:
Recover the key from the archive (also asynchronous),
both Locate and Get succeed.
usecase.details:
Recover
In: uuidKey
asynchronousIndicator=’true’
Out: asynchronousCorrelationValue

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (10) - Poll
usecase.description:
Recover the key from the archive (also asynchronous),
both Locate and Get succeed.
usecase.details:
Poll*
In: asynchronousCorrelationValue

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (11) - Get (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Recover the key from the archive (also asynchronous),
both Locate and Get succeed.
usecase.details:
Get (symmetric key)
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 10.1 (12) - Destroy
usecase.description: To clean up, delete the key.
usecase.details:
Destroy
In: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 11.1 (0) - Create (symmetric key)
usecase.description:
Pass a Credential object in the message header in all requests
for identification purposes (how the Credential object is used
is defined in [KMIP-Prof]). Create a symmetric key and set the
Operation Policy Name attribute to “default”. Using another
Credential, attempt to perform a Get operation batched with a
Get Atttribute List on the created symmetric key – according
to the Default Operation Policy, both these request SHALL fail,
and with the Batch Error Continuation Option set to “Continue”,
the client SHALL also receive both response payloads. Using the
initially used Credential, destroy the object and get the
Destroy Date attribute.
usecase.details:
Create (symmetric key)
In (header):
credential={
credentialType=’1’,
credentialValue={ username=”Fred”, password=”password1” }
} In:
objectType=’00000002’,
attributes={
CryptographicAlgorithm=’AES’,
CryptographicLength=’128’,
CryptographicUsageMask=‘0000000C’,
Name={ NameValue=‘PolicyKey’, NameType=’00000001’ },
OperationPolicyName=’default’,
CryptographicParameters={ BlockCipherMode=’1’, PaddingMethod=’3’, HashingAlgorithm=’4’}
}

usecase.name: Use Case 11.1 (1) - Client A: Get Attributes, Get
usecase.description:
Using another Credential, attempt to perform a Get operation batched with a
Get Atttribute List on the created symmetric key – according
to the Default Operation Policy, both these request SHALL fail,
and with the Batch Error Continuation Option set to “Continue”,
the client SHALL also receive both response payloads.
usecase.details:
Client A
Get Attributes, Get
In (header):
credential={
credentialType=’1’,
credentialValue={ username=”Fred”, password=”password1” }
}
In: attributeName=’Operation Policy Name’
In: uuidKey
Out: attributes={ OperationPolicyName=’Default’ }
Out: objectType = ‘00000002’, uuidKey, symmetricKey

usecase.name: Use Case 11.1 (2) - Client B: Get (symmetric key), Get Attribute List
usecase.description:
Using another Credential, attempt to perform a Get operation batched with a
Get Atttribute List on the created symmetric key – according
to the Default Operation Policy, both these request SHALL fail,
and with the Batch Error Continuation Option set to “Continue”,
the client SHALL also receive both response payloads.
usecase.details:
Client B
Get (symmetric key), Get Attribute List
In (header):
credential={
credentialType=’1’,
credentialValue={ username=”Barney”, password=”secret2” }
}
BatchOrderOption=’true’,
BatchErrorContinuationOption=’Continue’
In: uuidKey
In: uuidKey
Out: Operation Failed, Permission Denied
Out: Operation Failed, Permission Denied

usecase.name: Use Case 11.1 (3) - Destroy
usecase.description:
Using the initially used Credential, destroy the object
and get the Destroy Date attribute.
usecase.details:
Client A
Get Attributes, Get
In (header):
credential={
credentialType=’1’,
credentialValue={ username=”Fred”, password=”password1” }
}
In: uuidKey
Out: uuidKey

usecase.name: Use Case 11.1 (4) - Get Attributes
usecase.description: Using the initially used Credential, get the Destroy Date attribute.
usecase.details:
Client A
Get Attributes, Get
In (header):
credential={
credentialType=’1’,
credentialValue={ username=”Fred”, password=”password1” }
}
In: uuidKey
attributeNames={ ‘Destroy Date’ }
Out: uuidKey,
attributes={ DestroyDate=’ 0x000000004B9F8B4D’ }

usecase.name: Use Case 12.1 (0) - Query (operations, objects)
usecase.description:
Perform a Query operation, querying the Operations
and Objects supported by the server, with a restriction
on the Maximum Response Size set in the request header.
Since the resulting Query response is too big, an error
is returned. Increase the Maximum Response Size,
resubmit the Query request, and get a successful response.
usecase.details:
Query (operations, objects)
In (header): maximumResponseSize=’256’
In: queryFunctions={ ‘00000001’, ‘00000002’ }
Out: Operation Failed, Response Too Large

usecase.name: Use Case 12.1 (1) - Query (operations, objects)
usecase.description:
Perform a Query operation, querying the Operations
and Objects supported by the server, with a restriction
on the Maximum Response Size set in the request header.
Since the resulting Query response is too big, an error
is returned. Increase the Maximum Response Size,
resubmit the Query request, and get a successful response.
usecase.details:
Query (operations, objects)
In (header): maximumResponseSize=’2048’
In: queryFunctions={ ‘00000001’, ‘00000002’ }
Out: operations, objects
